content: Actually, President Obama is just doing what he said he was going to do. This was from a Jan,19/09 article: >http://www.venezuelanalysis.com/news/4125 "Mérida, January 19th, 2009 (Venezuelanalysis.com)-- In statements to the press over the weekend, the president-elect of the United States, Barack Obama, and Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez intensified their critiques of each other while reiterating their mutual desire to improve relations, leaving much uncertainty as to how diplomatic relations will take shape following Obama’s inauguration as the 44th president of the U.S. Tuesday. In the wake of widely-circulated news about meetings between opposition leaders and U.S. State Department officials in Puerto Rico last week, Chávez expressed skepticism toward the incoming Obama administration, demanding actions that show that the U.S. will put a halt to its long history of interventions in the affairs of its southern neighbors." Chavez then said, "I demand of the new president of the United States that he does not mess with Venezuela, because Venezuela is a free and sovereign country,” said Chávez, whose administration has purchased the majority share of all oil production in Venezuela and who strongly denounces U.S. government funding for domestic opposition groups." President Obama then said,"Venezuela is a country of critical importance to commerce in the region, it is an important provider of petroleum. We are willing to begin diplomatic conversations about how to improve relations,” said Obama. He added that “all countries in the region of have something of importance to contribute.” The article goes on to state that Obama will meet with Cuba if President Raul Castro is willing to give Cubans more personal freedom. As we speak major American telecommunications companies are jumping all over the new attitude out of Washington. Castro has said he's willing to talk and "everything is on the table". Obama called Chavez "a force that has impeded progress in the region.” Chávez responded in kind Monday, calling the U.S. the world’s top exporter of terrorism. He harshly criticized Obama’s silence about the bloody invasion of Gaza by Israel, the U.S.’s principal ally in the Middle East. “You ask [Obama] his opinion about the massacre of innocent children in Palestine, and he does not respond,” Chávez said. If under Obama’s administration the U.S.’s wars and interventions in foreign states continue as they have under the Bush administration, said Chávez, this will be “a new fiasco for his own people and for the world.” They weren't buddy-pal then. But Obama has said way up front that "Our responsibility as Americans is not to dictate policies… but to find cooperation and mutual interest.” That's what he seems to be doing and since most Americans heard that and made him the President, I figure this is what most Americans want too. If he can figure out a way to deal with Chavez in that vein, I say right on. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Thud357L, Sat 18 April 2009 05:20 PM
reply: Actually, President Obama is just doing what he said he was going to do. This was from a Jan,19/09 article: >http://www.venezuelanalysis.com/news/4125 "Mérida, January 19th, 2009 (Venezuelanalysis.com)-- In statements to the press over the weekend, the president-elect of the United States, Barack Obama, and Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez intensified their critiques of each other while reiterating their mutual desire to improve relations, leaving much uncertainty as to how diplomatic relations will take shape following Obama’s inauguration as the 44th president of the U.S. Tuesday. Chavez then said, "I demand of the new president of the United States that he does not mess with Venezuela, because Venezuela is a free and sovereign country,” said Chávez, whose administration has purchased the majority share of all oil production in Venezuela and who strongly denounces U.S. government funding for domestic opposition groups." President Obama then said,"Venezuela is a country of critical importance to commerce in the region, it is an important provider of petroleum. We are willing to begin diplomatic conversations about how to improve relations,” said Obama. He added that “all countries in the region of have something of importance to contribute.” The article goes on to state that Obama will meet with Cuba if President Raul Castro is willing to give Cubans more personal freedom. As we speak major American telecommunications companies are jumping all over the new attitude out of Washington. Castro has said he's willing to talk and "everything is on the table". Obama called Chavez "a force that has impeded progress in the region.” Chávez responded in kind Monday, calling the U.S. the world’s top exporter of terrorism. He harshly criticized Obama’s silence about the bloody invasion of Gaza by Israel, the U.S.’s principal ally in the Middle East. “You ask [Obama] his opinion about the massacre of innocent children in Palestine, and he does not respond,” Chávez said. If under Obama’s administration the U.S.’s wars and interventions in foreign states continue as they have under the Bush administration, said Chávez, this will be “a new fiasco for his own people and for the world.” They weren't buddy-pal then. But Obama has said way up front that "Our responsibility as Americans is not to dictate policies… but to find cooperation and mutual interest.” That's what he seems to be doing and since most Americans heard that and made him the President, I figure this is what most Americans want too. content: This is total politics aside. We have two countries that have said they don't like us at all right now. Some said very bad things about us. I think that is a nice way to put it. Do we walk away and just make believe they are not thier? No, I feel we need to keep the door open to any country that has Nukes or too much money and they can buy what they want. Do we kiss up to them? Not at all. I have to ask you folks, what would you have us do?

If under Obama’s administration the U.S.’s wars and interventions in foreign states continue as they have under the Bush administration, said Chávez, this will be “a new fiasco for his own people and for the world.” They weren't buddy-pal then. But Obama has said way up front that "Our responsibility as Americans is not to dictate policies… but to find cooperation and mutual interest.” That's what he seems to be doing and since most Americans heard that and made him the President, I figure this is what most Americans want too. If he can figure out a way to deal with Chavez in that vein, I say right on. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Thud357L, Sat 18 April 2009 05:20 PM
title: President Obama & Hugo Chavez new Best friends..

This knee jerk reaction is overboard and embarrassing. Sometimes a smile and a handshake is just a smile and a handshake.

content: This is total politics aside. We have two countries that have said they don't like us at all right now. Some said very bad things about us. I think that is a nice way to put it. Do we walk away and just make believe they are not thier? No, I feel we need to keep the door open to any country that has Nukes or too much money and they can buy what they want. Do we kiss up to them? Not at all. I have to ask you folks, what would you have us do?
